Sometimes called 'referees', your indepe: (Welsh) Sometimes called 'referees', your independent assessors will give us their opinion on your suitability for this role.
We'll only contact them if you pass the: (Welsh) We'll only contact them if you pass the first round of shortlisting.
It is important that you choose the righ: (Welsh) It is important that you choose the right assessor.
if you are a salaried judicial office ho: (Welsh) if you are a salaried judicial office holder, you need 2 judicial assessors
if you are a professional with one or mo: (Welsh) if you are a professional with one or more fee-paid judicial roles, you need one professional and one judicial assessor; the judicial assessor should be the judge who can provide examples most relevant to the role for which you are applying
ideally you should choose someone from y: (Welsh) ideally you should choose someone from your current employment or who has knowledge of your work in a judicial or professional capacity. If you work or practice independently, you may wish to choose someone (such as a judge) who has seen you practice and can provide good examples of your skills in relation to the required competencies.
a senior partner or head of chambersA: (Welsh) a senior partner or head of chambers
a judicial office holder who can give ex: (Welsh) a judicial office holder who can give examples of your professional work
a client (including a local authority of: (Welsh) a client (including a local authority official) or a magistrate
a line manager if you are from a non-leg: (Welsh) a line manager if you are from a non-legal background; if there is no line manager, then a current or former colleague or client
the senior judge of the court, jurisdict: (Welsh) the senior judge of the court, jurisdiction or circuit where you sit most often
the Senior President or Lord President (: (Welsh) the Senior President or Lord President (Scotland) if you are a Chamber/Tribunal President
the Lord Justice Clerk or Sheriff Princi: (Welsh) the Lord Justice Clerk or Sheriff Principal if you are a Sheriff (Scotland only)
your appraising judge if you sit on a tr: (Welsh) your appraising judge if you sit on a tribunal
If you are unable to provide one of the: (Welsh) If you are unable to provide one of the above, consider another judge who has first-hand knowledge of your work. If you are unable to provide any judicial assessor, please contact us giving your reasons writing.
If you are applying for a: (Welsh) If you are applying for a
you should choose assessors who know you: (Welsh) you should choose assessors who know you well and who can give clear examples of your abilities.
a former colleague, manager or client wh: (Welsh) a former colleague, manager or client who is familiar with the way you work
someone for whom you do voluntary work: (Welsh) someone for whom you do voluntary work
If you have been on maternity leave or a: (Welsh) If you have been on maternity leave or a career break, there is no time limit on how recently you have worked with your assessor, although where possible within the last 2 years is recommended so they can provide recent examples.
another individual who is applying for a: (Welsh) another individual who is applying for a role in the same exercise
a relative (even if you work or have wor: (Welsh) a relative (even if you work or have worked with them in a professional capacity)

for this exercise before completing this: (Welsh) for this exercise before completing this section. The Leadership Judge statement of suitability will contribute to your overall assessment alongside the evidence you have provided in your statement of suitability and written work. It should provide evidence that you can demonstrate the skills relevant to the Skills and Abilities for this role. No other references are sought for section 9(1) authorisation, only a statement of suitability from your Leadership Judge.
